Immigration attitudes among voters remain a contentious political issue, with exposure to different groups potentially shaping public opinion on immigration policy. Using data from a 2016 experiment conducted on train platforms in Georgia with 115 registered voters, we examine whether exposure to Spanish-speakers causally affects attitudes toward immigration.
